pr_title: chore(engine): draft new implementation of the BPMN lifecycle

timeline.message:
chore(engine): introduce new bpmn processing

Includes new implementation for:

- service task
- exclusive gateway
- multi instance
- boundary event
- sub process

This is a combination of 46 commits.

timeline.bodyText: Why?
timeline.author: Zelldon
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,150 @@ +/* + * Copyright Camunda Services GmbH and/or licensed to Camunda Services GmbH under + * one or more contributor license agreements. See the NOTICE file distributed + * with this work for additional information regarding copyright ownership. + * Licensed under the Zeebe Community License 1.0. You may not use this file + * except in compliance with the Zeebe Community License 1.0. + */ +package io.zeebe.engine.nwe; + +import io.zeebe.engine.processor.workflow.deployment.model.element.ExecutableFlowElement; + +/** + * The business logic of a BPMN element. + * + *

The execution of an element is divided into multiple steps that represents the lifecycle of + * the element. Each step defines a set of actions that can be performed in this step. The + * transition to the next step must be triggered explicitly in the current step.

replies.bodyText:
Which part is unclear for you?

The transition to the next step must be triggered explicitly in the current step.

The transition must be triggered explicitly because the next step may depend on the element or the current instance. For example, a multi-instance activity with an empty input collection is completed immediately. Otherwise, it creates child instances and waits for their completion.
replies.author: saig0

replies.bodyText: I have the feeling we always are blocked by the multi instance 😅 Could we handle it differently. So for example transform it dynamically to parallel gw and multiple service tasks ? 😁
replies.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText:
Could we handle it differently. So for example transform it dynamically to parallel gw and multiple service tasks ?

Interesting idea but I see some problems. The multi-instance is like a container that can be canceled via boundary event. The current solution, especially with the new processor, looks nice so far 😉
replies.author: saig0

replies.bodyText:
. The multi-instance is like a container that can be canceled via boundary event

Which would be possible if you model as a subprocess
replies.author: Zelldon

timeline.bodyText: Here in the interface you already know that the next step will be activated, but before you mentioned that needs to be triggered by the impl?
timeline.author: Zelldon
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,150 @@ +/* + * Copyright Camunda Services GmbH and/or licensed to Camunda Services GmbH under + * one or more contributor license agreements. See the NOTICE file distributed + * with this work for additional information regarding copyright ownership. + * Licensed under the Zeebe Community License 1.0. You may not use this file + * except in compliance with the Zeebe Community License 1.0. + */ +package io.zeebe.engine.nwe; + +import io.zeebe.engine.processor.workflow.deployment.model.element.ExecutableFlowElement; + +/** + * The business logic of a BPMN element. + * + *

The execution of an element is divided into multiple steps that represents the lifecycle of + * the element. Each step defines a set of actions that can be performed in this step. The + * transition to the next step must be triggered explicitly in the current step. + * + * @param the type that represents the BPMN element + */ +public interface BpmnElementProcessor { + + /** @return the class that represents the BPMN element */ + Class getType(); + + /** + * The element is entered (initial step). Perform every action to initialize the element. + * + *

Possible actions: + * + *

    + *
  • apply input mappings + *
  • open event subscriptions + *
+ * + * Next step: activated.

replies.bodyText: As mentioned before, the next action may depend on the specific element or runtime data (e.g. variables). Also, we only want to go to the next step if no incident was raised.
replies.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: Why new ? :D
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: This is a temporary debug statement that may help us while developing 😛
replies.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: I don't think you want to log this in the hot path right? 😅 probably make sense to put that on trace.
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: Same here, this is just a temporary debug log statement that helps us to see that our new processor is actually called 😅
replies.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: Could also have this as enum map :D
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: True. But I don't see the benefit of an enum map here.
replies.author: saig0

timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: We will throw an exception here eventually 😉
replies.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: Why?
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: A temporary reason because of multi-instance. This check will be removed when the processors for sub-process and process are implemented
replies.author: saig0

replies.bodyText: Maybe we need to add a todo here, so we don't forget
replies.author: korthout

timeline.bodyText: Why we sometimes throw exceptions and sometimes return null? 😅
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: Returning null is just a temporary solution caused by the current multi-instance implementation 😅
replies.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: shouldn't we check the ok value?
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText:
Nope. ok is just ok 😛
In this case, ok is from type Void and we don't want to consume it.
replies.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: What is the difference between our old Tuple class and now this either class ? 😅
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText:
Either is a way more powerful 🚀
It has basically nice functions like map() and flatMap() that allows chaining the method calls and make it more readable.
replies.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: can we have comment why this could happen?
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: I think the event trigger is removed when the element (i.e. its event scope) is left. I will add this as a comment.
replies.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: What is the benefit here to use this either?
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText:
It allows chaining the method calls. See here:
variableMappingBehavior
        .applyInputMappings(context, element)
        .flatMap(ok -> eventSubscriptionBehavior.subscribeToEvents(element, context))
        .ifRightOrLeft(
            ok -> stateTransitionBehavior.transitionToActivated(context),
            failure -> incidentBehavior.createIncident(failure, context));

Without the Either, this logic is a mess. We need to create an incident is something bad happens while applying the input mappings or subscribing to the events. If everything is ok then we can take the transition to the next state.
replies.author: saig0

replies.bodyText: thanks
replies.author: Zelldon

timeline.bodyText: what is this magic number? 😅
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText:
Yeah. This is scary 😱
This is from the current implementation. We will tackle it when looking at the state.
replies.author: saig0

timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: It would be nice but no 😅 See the comments above.
replies.author: saig0

timeline.author: Zelldon

timeline.bodyText: I love it that you use our exception message pattern 👍
timeline.author: Zelldon

timeline.bodyText: Why we need that class? 🤔
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText:
Currently, the stream writer is passed in the stream processor when calling it.
public void processRecord(
      final TypedRecord<WorkflowInstanceRecord> record,
      final TypedResponseWriter responseWriter,
      final TypedStreamWriter streamWriter,
      final Consumer<SideEffectProducer> sideEffect) {

Since we decided to not pack the stream writer in the context, like the current implementation, because it doesn't belong to runtime data. Instead, we decided to have a proxy that can be injected as a usual dependency.
replies.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: What is happening here?
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText:
As you can see nothing 😆
It is not yet implemented -> #4469
replies.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: Why we need to rewrite the collection?
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: It is the same logic as the current implementation. We need to insert an element into the collection. Feel free to suggest another approach (in a separate issue maybe).
replies.author: saig0

timeline.bodyText: What happens in these cases?
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: It is not yet implemented -> #4474
replies.author: saig0

timeline.author: Zelldon

timeline.bodyText: why we need a long here?
timeline.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: I don't know. It's coming from the MsgPackReader.
replies.author: saig0

replies.bodyText: It was considered a bug by Sonar. And although unlikely to cause any problem, I do think this is slightly better
replies.author: korthout
